item.title: Security | Fired instruments filmed to touch themselves
item.description: Secretary for Security, Wong Sio Chak, decided to say goodbye to the three instructs of the Macao Security Forces (ESFSM) Higher School involved in a video in play with the private parts. The application of the penalty, within the scope of a disciplinary proceeding, was revealed through the Secretary's Office Portal. The case built in September 2023, when a video was shared on social networks, which became Viral, in which two instructs emerged in games that involved their intimate parts. Following the disclosure of the images, a disciplinary process was filed to decide the future of the three involved. “In early September 2023, a short film circulated on the Internet with two men to commit indecent behaviors. After preliminary investigation, it was confirmed that both are instructing to receive training at the Macao Higher School of Security Forces,” was reported at the opening of the survey. In the course of the investigation, in the first phase, it was announced that the three instructs were "eliminated by moral misconduct, in the assessment of the" Personal Merit "module." However, more recently, the application of a most serious dismissal penalty has been confirmed. "The Macao Security Forces Higher School has already completed disciplinary proceedings, and the penalty of extinction of the public employment bond was applied to the three instructions, by order of the Secretary for Security," was nominated. According to the general rules, the instructs may appeal the decision to the MSAR courts in order to avoid the decision made.

item.title: Cooperation | Sam hu fai bet on Heilongjiang to diversify economy
item.description:
During a meeting between the Chief Executive and the representatives of Heilongjiang were signed several memos in areas such as Industry, Chinese Medicine, Education or Commerce
The chief executive expects Macao to be able to use Heilongjiang's industrial base to diversify the local economy. The hope was left during a meeting, at the closed door, between Sam Hou Fai and Xu Qin, secretary of the Provincial Committee of Heilongjiang of the Communist Party of China and president of the Permanent Committee of the Provincial Popular Assembly, which took place on Monday. According to the official version, Sam Hou Fai pointed out that “Heilongjiang has a solid industrial base, with rich ecological resources” and argued that both parties should use “different advantages in resources and industries” to reinforce cooperation, and contribute to the diversification of Macau's economy. As he has argued in meetings with interior representatives, the Chief Executive also indicated that there is a perspective of “broad” cooperation, in the level of “economy, trade, science, technology, education, cultural and sports” to “inject a new dynamic in promoting the development of the proper diversification of the Macao economy”. The Chief Executive also pointed out that the Government of MSAR will fulfill “the spirit of the important speeches of President XI Jinping”, which is “persisting in the principle of a country, two systems”, fully play the role of Macao as a link between China and Portuguese-speaking countries, actively articulates with major national strategies, such as the initiative ‘a track, a route’ and the construction of the great Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau ”. Protocol signature The meeting also served to sign different protocols, whose reach were not revealed in the statement that made the report of the meeting. The signed protocols were the “Memorandum of Tourism Cooperation between the Department of Culture and Tourism of the Province of Heilongjiang and the Directorate of MSAR Tourism Services”, the “Memorandum of Cooperation between the Heilongjiang Province Department and the Institute for the Promotion of Trade and Investment of the MSAR”, the “Memorandum of Cooperation between the Department of Education of the Province of Heilongjiang and Directorate of MSAR Youth Education and Youth Development Services ”. The “Strategic Cooperation Agreement in the area of ​​traditional Chinese medicine between MSAR health services and the Management of Traditional Chinese Medicine of the Province of Heilongjiang”, the “Exchange and Cooperation Agreement in the Sports Area between Heilongjiang Province and the Institute of Sports of Masters”, “Memorandum of Cooperation, Steel deepening of the exchange and development of youth between the Heilongjiang Youth Federation and the Directorate of Youth Education and Development Services of MSAR ”, and the“ Cooperation Agreement on the Construction of Heilongjiang Medicines Certification and Product Innovation 'between the University of Macao and the Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine of the Province Heilongjiang ”.

item.title: Artificial Intelligence in Macao Culinary
item.description: (Continuation of the March 20 edition) As the food industry adapts to new technologies, bosses take on new roles as curators of experiences rather than mere producers. The combination of human creativity with AI capabilities can lead to unparalleled gastronomic offers. The impact of AI on consumer behavior cannot be ignored. The emergence of mobile applications that use AI algorithms to predict gastronomic preferences can change the way residents and tourists experience food in Macao. Food delivery services, such as FoodPanda and Uber Eats that do not yet operate in Macao, use AI to suggest restaurants based on users' habits and preferences. This personalization increases customer satisfaction by presenting options that closely align with individual tastes. In addition, food sustainability is another critical area to which AI can contribute positively. In Macao, like in other regions, there is increasing sensitization for the environmental impact of food production and waste. AI can optimize supply chain logistics, predict demand and reduce excesses, leading to more sustainable practices. For example, algorithms can analyze seasonal trends to suggest menus that align with available ingredients, reducing waste and ensuring that customers receive fresh offers. Collaboration between food brands and AI development companies is also becoming predominant. Partnerships may arise with the aim of creating innovative culinary products that capitalize on AI data and knowledge. For example, collaborations between chefs and technology companies can result in products designed specifically for Macanese cuisine, combining traditional recipes with AI -generated recommendations for the purchase and use of ingredients. The future of AI in the gastronomic landscape of Macau is promising. With continuous advances in automatic learning and data analysis, we can expect even greater AI integration into kitchens. For example, kitchen robots that may replicate the accuracy of human heads may become common. These robots will be able to improve techniques such as cooking and precise emphasis, improving the consistency of food production. In addition, virtual reality and AI can join to revolutionize gastronomic experiences in Macao. Imagine that customers can participate in virtual cooking classes guided by top chiefs, learning how to prepare traditional dishes while exploring the integration of Ia in real time. These experiences would promote culinary education, maintaining the essence of heritage. In the light of such advances, the ethical considerations surrounding AI in the culinary arts should also be carefully analyzed. The question of the displacement of jobs due to automation is a pressing concern. As AI assumes tasks traditionally performed by humans, bosses and kitchen staff can see their functions evolve. The formation and improvement of competences will become fundamental to ensure that cooking professionals can prosper in an IMI environments. Educational institutions in Macao must respond to this need, incorporating culinary technology courses in their curricula. This initiative will prepare aspiring bosses not only to dominate traditional cooking techniques, but also to understand the role of AI in modern kitchen. By combining the traditional teaching of culinary arts with technology, the next generation of bosses can enjoy the best of both worlds. The use of AI in Macau cuisine means an important turning point in the way food is prepared, served and experienced. By improving operational efficiency and customizing gastronomic experiences, AI brings a new era of culinary possibilities. Influential heads like André Chiang are leading the process, demonstrating how technology can coexist with tradition. However, the authenticity of Macanese cuisine should be preserved as we adopt these innovations. By addressing this weighted integration, Macau can remain a vibrant gastronomic center, balancing the richness of his heritage with the exciting possibilities of the digital age. The interaction between AI and traditional macao cuisine is a reflection of broader trends in the culinary arts globally. The trip of mixing the AI ​​with Macau's cultural heritage is just starting, but has a vast potential to shape the future of food. Resistance to embrace it can mean stagnation, while opening to innovation can lead to a prosperous and dynamic culinary scenario in the future.

item.title: LIMITS OF WORK
item.description: On March 17, the Hong Kong Census and Statistics Department released data showing that approximately 12,900 people worked on digital food delivery platforms and other goods over the past year. 52,5 por cento destes trabalhadores têm entre 15 e 39 anos, mais de metade tem menos de 40 e 24,2 por cento mais de 50 anos. 64.7 percent of respondents stated that this work is their main source of income, 61 percent receives less than $ 5,000 from Hong Kong (HKD) per month and 37.1 percent earns more than 15,000 hkd a month. 53.9 percent work less than 44 hours a week, 24.9 percent over 44 hours per week and 21.2 percent of these workers claim not to have a fixed time. 68.6 por cento trabalham apenas para uma plataforma de entregas a cada dia. 91.3 percent of respondents say they have started working in this business because it is easy to enter, having a flexible working method and having great control over methods and procedures. 98.2 percent claim to have more maneuver field to balance work with personal life. 45 percent are attracted to this work due to salary. Other data previously issued by the Hong Kong government show that the average salary of these workers was 22,000 USD between October and December 2024. By comparison, only 37.1 percent earn more than 15,000 USD, showing that they usually receive wages below average. Office employees in Hong Kong usually work from 9am to 6pm during the week and another four hours on Saturdays, which means a total of 49 hours of weekly work. Excluding the break from an hour for lunch from Monday to Friday, exactly 44 hours. Since 53.9 percent of distributors work less than 44 hours per week, it is reasonable that their salaries will be lower than the market average. 98.2 percent of people who make deliveries say they do this service by giving them more room to balance their work with family life. This demonstrates that the new generation pay more attention to the balance between work and personal life, a different phenomenon from the “tele-work” that emerged during the epidemic. The “tele-work” means working from home because it is difficult to evaluate the limit between work and family life. As people working on delivery platforms can control their working hours, the problem of defining the border between work and leisure is very small. The three main limits that define the exercise of labor functions are psychological, temporal and physical. Psychological boundaries are rules created by individuals who determine specific thoughts, behaviors and emotions, which means that one should have a rational attitude when working and an emotional attitude when one is in family. Time limits mean defining working hours, turning off duties outside this time, and dedicating this extra labor time to home and family. The physical limit is defined by the workplace. When you go to the office you will work, when you leave the work ended. The statistical data of delivery platforms show that people choose to collaborate with them mainly because they have more room to control their hours and work model. This phenomenon indicates that the new generation values ​​the existence of boundaries to work time and, in terms of psychological limits, seeks to have more control over their work. In the post-epicide era, it is given greater importance to the balance between professional and family career. Limits theory helps companies understand and better manage work and family boundaries, thus achieving better balance and allowing workers' quality of life to improve. In Hong Kong, delivery platform distributors earn less. Although it has a better notion of the limits of work and a happier family life, material goods that can give to the family are limited. These workers need to achieve balance between family life and material goods. From a business point of view, giving workers more space and flexibility, as well as broader borders, will help recruit a new generation of employees. item.title: Let us be practical
item.description: The annual plenary session of the National Popular Congress and the National Committee of the Chinese people's Political Advisory Conference, held in Beijing, has recently ended. One of the main concerns of Macau representatives was the “Integration of Macao and Hengqin”. I transcribe an excerpt from a conversation I heard as I had breakfast, "Are you going to buy an apartment in Hengqin?" "No, if I wanted a house, I bought it in Zhuhai, because it gets closer to Macau." Living in Hengqin certainly has its advantages. Many students from China who study at Macao universities live in Hengqin and catch the bus to the mud every day. There are also many residents and newly arrived people living in Hengqin for reasons related to work or children's school. But even if they come to live in Hengqin, which has an area of ​​106.46 square kilometers, 100,000 people, or even more than 200,000, is still not much. At the time when the housing fractions of the “new neighborhood of Macau” were for sale, there were many restrictions, which were being raised over time on the grounds of “development policy changes with development”. But deep down, they are "policies that give in to reality." In fact, whether it is politics or economics, the practical sense is imposed. I am not opposed to the improvement of the legal framework aimed at the “integration of Macao and Hengqin,” as it is necessary to clarify the difference between “in -depth cooperation zone between Guangdong and Macau in Hengqin” and “New Zone of Hengqin”. If we think about the efforts that are being developed for the “integration of Macao and Hengqin,” we will see that Macau has played a more active role than Guangdong Province. In the case of Macao, I suggest that hengqin circulation of all types of vehicles from the city is allowed. However, how can Hengqin attract residents of Macao to live there and contribute to their development if there is not even a public parking park for Macao vehicles at the Hengqin border post? If there are those who ask that the “Macao vehicle circulation policy in Guangdong province” has already made it difficult to survive companies in the North Zone of Macao, then if these vehicles are allowed to circulate in Hengqin, will this not even have negative consequences for Macao's economy? In my opinion, the introduction of reforms in the commercial sector is just a way to get out of your current situation. It is a priority to end the monopoly of the commercial sector, to open the economy to different markets, to develop and use the unoccupied land as much as possible, while reducing the negative impact of “road works” on companies and store owners. For example, the Jockey Club of Macao has been closed since last year and the clues have been covered with grass. However, the Macao government has not announced any development plan for the site, thus being wasted valuable resources. Perhaps the Macao government can be inspired by the operational management of Hong Kong's “Kai Tak Sports Park”. As for this subject, the Macao Executive can grant one of six resort and leisure companies integrated the Jockey Club's land development and management rights for a given period of time, which can somehow help create a new commercial zone that attracts the consumption of more tourists. It would also be important to create political incentives and/or flexibility of restrictions on companies to attract traders to settle in the old neighborhoods and community neighborhoods throughout the city. If we look at the “reordering of the amendment street and four other streets of the parish of Santo António” that took place a few years ago, and compare the agitated environment that existed before and after reordering, it becomes evident that the “ideas” that come out of those who “are sitting in their offices” have to be put to the test to be effective. We impose on reality only usually results in disaster. The “Integration of Hengqin and Macau” is an ambitious venture that the homeland has entrusted to Macao. Before Hengqin is officially under the jurisdiction of Macao, the most important thing is to preserve and develop Macau.

item.title: Letters Route | From Mongolia to the old Portuguese colonies: the exhibitions
item.description:
The Rota das Letras literary festival features three photography exhibitions, two of them patents until April, which feature a diversity of themes and creative styles. João Miguel Barros collaborated in the curatorship of all of them: “Nomadic Time: An Introduction”, by Jessie Rao; “The wind blows on the prairie,” by Wang Zhengping; and “New Independences”, with images of photojournalist Alfredo Cunha. Here's a trip through three distinct worlds
If you photograph is counting, or transmitting speechlessly, there is then the bet of the Literary Festival Rota das Letras to present three distinct exhibitions, ranging from the distant scenarios of Mongolia to the ancient Portuguese colonies in Africa. João Miguel Barros, healer, also a photographer, helped curate them all, and at HM reveals some of the details of each project. In the case of “The wind blows on the prairie”, with work by Wang Zhengping, the curated was done in partnership with Risong. Available until April 28 at the TAP Seac Gallery, this was, “by far, the most challenging exhibition in curatorial terms,” he confessed. “I had to start from a set of about 300 files with images and choose the main narrative. I chose to focus the exhibition on the Mongolian horses project, which is what fascinates me the most, giving it more space, and completed it with the other project of the communities,” said João Miguel Barros, explaining that “it could have been the other way around, because he [Wang Zhengping] has two very well developed components over the time decades of work". In addition, the curator had to create "a dialogue between the size of the images and its placement in the gallery space, creating groups with its own identity." "I was very happy with the end result and I think I was able to surprise the artist, who confessed to me not waiting for this result," he said. Wang Zhengping is, besides photographer, ethnographer, being currently known as one of China's great contemporary photographers, especially for its artistic aspect. It began to obtain international recognition from 2015, being considered one of the top ten pioneers of Asian photography in the ranking of the Pixel photographic magazine. It has a work very focused on the horses that live in the Mongolia steppes, in the autonomous region of Mongolia Interior, a region that has marked its work a lot.
Decolonization For a completely different creative and themed field, João Miguel Barros organized “New Independences”, with images of photojournalist Alfredo Cunha, which can be seen in the former municipal slaughterhouse until Sunday. "Alfredo Cunha's show is an appetite for the big breath exhibition that is being built from root to come to Macau next year," he said. With the theme of Portuguese decolonization, which started after April 25, 1974, “new independence” focuses on Portuguese-speaking African countries, which lived more intensely this process of decolonization. However, the curator wanted to remove him "the institutional and political burden," selecting "hundreds of images sent by Alfredo to me from a more personal and humanist criterion." The curator then decided to group these images into five sets, entitled "places", "people", "to weapons", "arrivals and matches" and "rituals". “The images are very significant and reveal the great talent of one of the great names of Portuguese April 25 photography,” added João Miguel Barros. Alfredo Cunha began working in photography in 1970, having entered the newspapers the following year, starting at Amadora News. Since then he has collaborated with the most important Portuguese newspapers, such as the already missing century; The public or the Jornal de Notícias, having also been editor of the photography section. He was an official photographer of the Presidents of the Republic Ramalho Eanes and Mário Soares, receiving the Commendation of the Order of Infante D. Henrique in 1996. His work on the Revolution of Cloves, on April 25, 1974, and Portuguese decolonization, are among their best known photographic works. Nomadas in the hostel The third show integrated into the Rota das Letras Literary Festival is “Nomada Time: An Introduction”, inaugurated this Monday at SCM Hostel and which is evident until April 10th. “I brought Jessie [Rao] to Macau in the context of this festival because it is a disciple of Wang Zhengping and the fact that its project is also about Mongolia. The work that is exposed, which is all color, unlike Wang's show, which is totally black and white, shows a different and more experiential view of communities and people,” he explained. Although Jessie Rao is not a native of Mongolia, the truth is that she eventually captured something from the region's culture, demonstrating, in the curator's view, "a huge talent." "This project [nomada time] obtained the excellence award, which is the main prize, in Pingyao International Photography Festival last year. It captures the human side of people with a unique density, and its photographs are beautiful," he added.

item.title: Jockey Club | Cats adopted with health problems
item.description:
Among the 22 adopted cats living in the Macao Jockey Club, a outbreak of feline panleukopenia was detected, which led to the deaths of at least two animals. After the information was made public, the company of Macau Jockey Club announced the distribution of a support of 5,000 patacas to adopters
Among the 22 cats available for adoption by Macau Jockey Club and the animal animal protective society, at least eight were infected with feline panleucopenia and two died. The information was released by anima. According to the association, eight felines were diagnosed with parvovirus infections, which is regarded as highly contagious and dangerous. Among these eight, two died and six are, or were in serious condition, needing to receive expensive medical treatments. Detection of a surge of the disease in the cats that were in the Jockey Club is not a surprise, since on the day of adoptions there were three cats, of the 25 initially available, which were diagnosed with the disease. For this reason, only 22 cats were adopted during the campaign. Anima also reported that among these 22 cats only two had no health problems. However, there were other cases where felines had severe bronchitis, tooth fall, despite being only one year, and other respiratory system infections. “We deeply regret the heavy financial burden caused to adopters or the pain and suffering of adopted cats and kittens who died due to the virus,” was indicated. "We promise to continue to communicate actively with the Jockey Club of Macao to get compensation for the medical expenses incurred by adopters," he was added. In addition to the adoption cats promoted by Macau Jockey Club and anima, Mary Jean Reimer, actress, lawyer and activist for the animal rights of Hong Kong, also revealed that one of the Jockey Club cats who adopted positive tested for feline panleukopenia. Positive response When it issued the first statement, anima still did not confirm that the treatments of sick cats would be paid by Macau Jockey Club. Initially, it was feared that they would have to be the adopters to pay the costs. However, yesterday, almost 24 hours after the first publication reporting the problems, the company's administration agreed to distribute 5,000 patacas support for each cat adopted. Macau Jockey Club was involved in a new controversy with cats, when in the middle of this month, tried to send about 100 felines to the interior to an unknown destination that was never revealed. The sending of cats was approved by the Institute for municipal affairs, which in a statement even promised to ensure animal health conditions for transport to Zhuhai. However, several local animal protection associations have mobilized to prevent this outcome. In addition to the adoption promotion campaign, associations also received several of the cats. The animals were raised as bravery at Macau Jockey Club, where they had as their function hunting rats, as the use of space by horses prevented the use of chemicals. However, as they had not been sterilized, the cats reproduced until they were about 100. Now it is also known that they had developed several diseases.

item.title: Payments | Institutions teach the elderly how to use mobile phones
item.description:

Last year, the General Association of Respectful Elderly of Macao carried out an inquiry into the use of mobile phones by people over 60. Although more than 90 percent answered that he used mobile phone, 76.8 percent admitted not knowing how to make electronic payments and 18.6 percent of respondents stated that mobile data packages and mobile phones are expensive, minimizing their use. The statistics were presented by Deputy Leong Hong Sai, in a written interplies, in which he concludes that “the consciousness of the elderly about the use of intelligent technologies” is weak. In response, the president of the Institute of Social Action (IAS), Hon Wai, listed a series of measures designed to appeal the elders with technological knowledge. In order to “foster computer generalization”, IAS has encouraged social institutions “teaching the elderly how to use computer equipment, including smartphones, through recreational courses, workshops, courses or lectures”. Hon Wai highlighted the usefulness of using applications such as “Single Account”, “Bus Location” and “Macao Health Data Platform”. In addition, the president of IAS said that, to “demonstrate the affection for the elderly, CTT have been encouraging mobile telecommunications service operators to launch specially designed benefits for this age group”. Plans offer "unlimited data at restricted speed and allow the purchase of mobile phones at promotional prices." Warn The president of IAS also recalled that the older population can also enroll in courses of the Program for Development and Continuous Improvement for mobile phone applications and safe use of the internet. Hon Wai also stressed the effort to prevent the older population from being a victim of burlas. In addition to raising awareness in social institutions that offer services to the elderly, police authorities last year, 126 “Anti-Burial Lectures”, in which more than 8,300 people participated. Alongside this, last year, “the Judiciary Police went to Chinese restaurants, recreational, markets and vendin areas” to sensitize the elderly to be aware of burla schemes.

item.title: MIECF | Lusofonia companies look for business in renewable energy
item.description: A set of 26 companies from Portugal, Brazil and Timor-Leste will be present in Macao at the Forum and International Exhibition of Environmental Cooperation (MIECF), which runs from March 27 to 29, the organizers said yesterday. Lusophony exhibitors “will expose products related to new energies, waste management, wastewater treatment and environmental hygiene,” said the president of the Institute for the promotion of commerce and investment, Vincent U SENG. The event, which has been organized since 2008, aims to address topics such as carbonic neutrality, green and ecological mobility, and has activities such as the “Green Forum”, green exhibition, contact bags and a “green day of the public”. “Innovation and Green Development - Solutions for Construction of Beautiful Cities”, is this year's theme, which will be exposed in an area of ​​12,000 square meters, according to the organizers. This year, “we will also organize business visits to Hengqin and Zhuhai for representatives of Portuguese -speaking countries, and thus expand the influence of our platform to new international green business opportunities,” said U. item.title: Tokyo | Japanese newspaper correspondent killed in Gaza
item.description: A Palestinian correspondent from the Japanese newspaper The Asahi Shimbun was killed in the Gaza Strip, apparently by an Israeli attack. According to the newspaper, Mohammed Mansour, 29, died in the city of Khan Youis, in southern Gaza, on Monday. It is believed to have been killed by an attack by an Israelite missile. The newspaper initially told NHK that Mansour died with his wife and son still a baby, but then corrected the explanation, citing information that his wife and son were being treated in a hospital. Mansour, a native of Gaza, began working for The Asahi Shimbun in 2023. The young journalist worked at Rafah and Khan Youis, sending reports and photos about the evolution of the situation in Gaza. The newspaper issued a statement expressing the inevitable feeling of deep sadness and anger at his death. The publication emphasized that attacks on civilians, including journalists, can never be tolerated under any circumstances. Meanwhile, the Qatar-based Al Jazeera satellite TV station, said on Monday that one of its reporters was killed in another Israeli air strike in northern Gaza. Gaza authorities say the number of journalists killed in the territory has reached 208 since the conflict.

item.title: Thai Prime Minister survives the motion of distrust
item.description: The Prime Minister of Thailand, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, survived yesterday to a motion of distrust in Parliament, which questioned the management of the economy and the links to the former leader and father, Thaksin Shinawatra, convicted of corruption. Paetongtarn, 38, who took office in August, was supported by 319 deputies, against 161, who voted against it, totaling 500 members of the Chamber of Representatives, the Baixa do Parliament As planned, the leader was supported by the 11 parties of the government coalition, led by Puea Thai (Thai people), a platform linked to the Shinawatra clan. The motion was presented Monday by the Popular Party, in opposition, heir to the Avanzar party, dissolved last August by a controversial court decision. During the two sessions preceding the vote, the debate turned around the poor performance of the Thai economy and the alleged influence of Thaksin, who ruled the country between 2021 and 2006, the year that was removed from power by a military coup. Paetongtarn, a first-minister candidate for PUEA Thai in the May 2023 elections, reached the power in August 2024, after the then leader Srettha Thavisin, also from PEA Thai, was deprived by order of the Constitutional Court after appointing minister a corruption-convicted leader. Do what I say Thaksin, Thailand's most influential and polarizing politician in the last 20 years, has returned to the country after spending almost 15 years in exile the same day Srettha has taken office. The former leader was arrested on arrival at Bangkok, accused of corruption, but did not pass a night in prison, having been transferred on the same day to a hospital, where he was six months old, and then placed in house arrest until his release, days after his daughter had risen to power. Thaksin, 75, claims to be taken from politics, but occasionally admitted to advice to the current leader and was seen to preside over meetings with other prominent Thai political leaders. The Reform Party Advance won the May 2023 elections, but failed to govern due to a Senate veto, then composed of representatives linked to the extinct military council. The party was eventually dissolved by the Constitutional Court, following an electoral promise to alter the laws that protect the Thai Royal House of criticism. PEA Thai, which initially allied with Advance, eventually agreed with a coalition government in which parties are associated with the military, once enemies of the Shinawatras.

item.title: South Korea | Forest Fires have already made 24 dead
item.description:
The fireworks that triggered last Friday are sowing the chaos through the Asian country. In addition to destroying temples, houses and factories, the flames have already caused death to at least 24 people
The wind fires caused by the wind, which are among the worst in the history of South Korea, caused the death of 24 people, destroyed more than 200 structures and forced the evacuation of 27,000 people, according to the last balance. The death toll included a pilot who died after a helicopter dropped during efforts to contain forest fires in the city of Uiseong in the Southeast, one of the hardest areas, according to the authorities. The aircraft had no other crew. According to the National Fire Agency, at least 26 other people suffered varying degrees of injuries. An old Buddhist temple, houses, factories and vehicles are among the structures destroyed in forest fires. South Korea's acting president Han Duck-Soo said the forest fires that began last Friday are causing worse damage than many other previous forest fires. "The damage is increasing. We fear having forest fires damage we have never had before, so we have to concentrate all our capabilities to erase the fires by the end of this week," said Han. According to the official, about 4,650 firefighters, soldiers and other employees are on the ground, with the help of about 130 helicopters. Missing heritage The biggest fires occurred in Andong, in the counties of neighbors of Uiseong and Sancheong and in the city of Ulsan, according to the South Korean Ministry of Interior. The Uiseong fire destroyed almost half of more than 30 structures in Gounsa, a temple that was originally built in the seventh century. Korea Forest Service has raised forest fire alert to the highest level across the country on Tuesday, requiring local governments to designate more workers to respond to emergencies, increase the entrance restrictions to forest and parks and recommend that military units suspend royal exercises. Government authorities suspect that human error caused several fires.

item.title: Rangel highlights the importance of Chinese investment for the economy
item.description: Portuguese Foreign Minister Paulo Rangel highlighted yesterday the “important role” of Chinese investment in the Portuguese economy, during a meeting with Chinese counterparts Wang Yi, according to a statement issued by the Chinese authorities. The head of Portuguese diplomacy has invited “more Chinese companies to invest and prosper in Portugal” and indicated that Lisbon “is willing to reinforce cooperation with China in the domains of economics and commerce, energy, health, finance, infrastructure and ecological transformation”. Rangel stated that Portugal and China “have a long history of interaction” and that relations between the two countries “have been developing well,” reads the note widespread by the Chinese Foreign Ministry. Beijing and Lisbon “gave an example to the world” by solving the issue of Macao peacefully, he added. Quoted in the same statement, Wang Yi highlighted the “good tradition of respect and mutual support” between the two countries. "Portugal is one of the countries of the European Union that receives the most Chinese investment" per capita "," said the chief of Chinese diplomacy, who appealed to "widening cooperation in the domains of investment in projects, ecological transformation, digital economy, innovation and research, information and communication." Wang highlighted the role that Macau can play "like a bridge to promote the relationship between the two countries to achieve greater development." The Chinese diplomat expressed his "support for Europe in maintaining his strategic autonomy" and the hope "that Portugal play an active role in" healthy development of relations between China and Europe. " The two ministers “discussed issues of common interest, such as the 'crisis' in Ukraine,” according to the Chinese Foreign Ministry's statement, which no longer gave details. Weight -investor China has become, in the last decade, the fourth largest foreign direct investor in Portugal. Chinese, state and private companies have a global position evaluated at 11.2 billion euros in the Portuguese economy, according to Banco de Portugal. Investments cover the areas of energy, bank, safe or health. In 2018, the two countries signed a memorandum of understanding of the “Track and Route” initiative, a mega project of infrastructure launched by Beijing that aims to expand its global influence through the construction of ports, railways or self-destined.

item.title: Apple donates almost 4 me to Chinese University to train programmers
item.description: The American technology company Apple will donate 30 million Yuan to the Chinese university of Zhejiang, announced its executive president, Tim Cook, on a visit to Hangzhou, headquarters of technological giants Deepseek and Alibaba. The city, located in eastern China, is considered a technological epicenter of the country, at a time when the artificial intelligence sector (IA) is having a new boom in the region. The initiative is part of the Apple Mobile App Incubation Fund, a fund created to support the formation of entrepreneurial programmers and encourage the development of mobile applications in the iOS ecosystem. Through this program, participants will receive technical training, mentoring and access to investors and experts from the sector. "We believe that programming is a powerful tool that allows us to create, communicate and solve problems in totally new ways. We have the honor of deepening our collaboration from a decade with the University of Zhejiang to enable the next generation of programmers," said Cook. According to Apple, the company has allocated 50 million Yuan to the university in the last ten years. The mobile innovation contest, supported by Apple a decade ago, attracted more than 30,000 applications from nearly 1000 universities from “Greater China”. In recent years, specific students have been added to students without prior program track and recent entrepreneurs (“Launch Track), simultaneously widening their reach to less developed regions in the country. "We will work together with Apple to create a new generation of talents with integrity in terms of knowledge, skills, character and values," said Ren Shabo, secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC) at Zhejiang University. Commitment and investment Cook's visit to Hangzhou is part of his current tour of China, where he has reiterated Apple's commitment to the local market. On Monday, in Beijing, he met Chinese Minister Wang Wenta, whom he reaffirmed plans to increase investment in investigation, supply chain and social responsibility in the country. Cook made at least three trips to China last year to show his commitment to further increase the investment in the country and "take advantage of the opportunities offered by its opening." In one of these visits he said he gives his Chinese partners "great value", without whom the manufacturer "could not do what he does," and on another trip opened the largest Apple store in Asia, located in the eastern megalopolis of Xangai. Greater China is Apple's third largest market after America and Europe. However, iPhone sales have decreased in the region, partly due to increasing competition from local brands such as Huawei and the lack of AI functionality in the latest Californian company. According to The Wall Street Journal, Apple has been in conversations with several Chinese AI companies about a possible partnership to implement Apple Intelligence in China.

item.title: Government accuses Taiwan of “delivering the TSMC tray” to the United States
item.description: China yesterday accused Taiwan authorities of “delivering tray” to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's largest semiconductor manufacturer to the United States, where the company announced major investment and expansion plans. The Council of State's Office spokesman for the Taiwan affairs, Chen Binhua, lamented that "TSMC has become a piece of juicy meat on the cutting board, ready to be undone in pieces," according to state television CCTV. According to Chen, TSMC is becoming "an American company," which, according to him, is a sign that the Progressive Democratic Party (DPP) in Taiwan power, "only has in mind party selfishness and is not concerned with the well-being of the Taiwan compatriots or the interests of the industrial sector." The spokesman warned that the DPP "will move forward" on the "Taiwan's Sale and Destruction" and that the industrial sector and the people of the territory "will not only lose jobs, but also opportunities for future development." The spokesman accused Taiwan leader William Lai of "selling Taiwan" and "abuse of power." TSMC controls about 90 percent of the worldwide market for advanced semiconductors, essential for US companies such as Nvidia and Apple, and for technologies such as Artificial Intelligence. Rain TSMC CEO C.C. Wei announced earlier this month, from the White House, an investment of $ 100 billion in the US, which some analysts played as a gesture of goodwill to US President Donald Trump. The investment is intended to build three new factories, two advanced chips packaging facilities and a research and development center. These $ 100 billion join the investment of TSMC's $ 65 billion in Phoenix, Arizona, where there is a factory that started operating in late 2024 and plans to open two more factories in the coming years. Although TSMC defended these investments from a purely commercial perspective, the Taiwan government is looking for an approach to Trump, which threatened to impose rates up to 100 percent on Taiwanese chips and repeatedly accused the island of “usurping” the semiconductor industry in the United States. According to Taiwan's leader, TSMC's global expansion reinforces its leadership and the competitiveness of the Taiwan semiconductor industry.

item.title: Space | Beijing wants the launching platform of electromagnetic rockets by 2028
item.description:
The ambitious Chinese spatial expansion plan seeks to reduce expenses and promote access to the increasingly frequent space
China plans to develop the world's first electromagnetic rocket launch platform by 2028, in a project that seeks to reduce costs and increase the frequency of access to space. The system, developed by the private company Galactic Energy in collaboration with state research institutes, the Ziyang Municipal Government and China Aerospace Science and Industry Corporation (Casic), will use superconducting imons to accelerate rockets at supersonic speeds before ignition, in a structure similar to a maggev, but vertically oriented train. According to its creators, this technology would double the load capacity, significantly reduce operating costs and facilitate more frequent releases with less maintenance, the Hong Kong South China Morning Post post on Tuesday. The long-term objective is to make rocket launches as frequent, predictable and efficient as daily high-speed train trips, integrating them into a regularly used technological infrastructure. However, experts warned that there are still technical obstacles, such as flight accuracy and thermal resistance during the initial climb. The verification platform is being built by Casic and the Ziyang government. In September 2023, a magnetic levitation test using high temperature superconductors reached a speed of 234 kilometers per hour on a 380 meter track, as part of the project's initial technical checks. For exploiting Founded in 2018, Galactic Energy conducted 18 successful releases of its Ceres-1 rocket, with a total of 77 satellites placed in orbit. The most recent, on March 21, placed six meteorological satellites in a heliosyncron orbit. The company is also working on the development of CERES-2, with a payload capacity up to 3.5 tons compared to the 400 kilograms of the previous model. In September 2023, however, one of its releases failed due to “abnormal flight performance”, according to the company. A few days earlier, Galactic Energy had become the first Chinese private company to make a successful sea release. Chinese scientists have already begun to investigate similar systems to the lunar environment, with the aim of transporting materials such as the helium-3 of the terrestrial satellite surface using electromagnetic catapults, thus eliminating the need for large amounts of fuel. Although the plan is still in a preliminary phase, the initiative is part of the Chinese government strategy to consolidate its commercial aerospace industry. China has invested strongly in its space program in recent years, reaching Marcos such as the landing of the Chang'e 4 probe on the hidden side of the moon, the arrival in Mars and the construction of the Tiangong space station, which will operate for about ten years.

item.title: Vera Lúcia Raposo, jurist and teacher: “It was propagated today as a virus”
item.description:
Vera Lúcia Raposo presented on Wednesday at the University of Macao the new regulatory framework of the European Union for Artificial Intelligence, in a session promoted by the Institute of European Studies of Macao. The former Macao University officer argues that China is gaining the race in an area that has never been so present in our lives
Spoke on Wednesday of “Ai Act” approved by the European Union (EU). Specifically, what are the main points of this document? This is the Artificial Intelligence Regulation (IA) published last year in the EU official newspaper. It is a European law, but it is also, so far, the most detailed legal regime about the products surrounding AI. Is it difficult to legislate on the AI ​​at this preliminary phase? Maybe we will never stop being at this stage. Notice, AI did not come up with ChatgPT or anything that looks like. Since the middle of the last century, and even before, but especially since Alan Turing's 'Paper' that Ia exists, first in the laboratory, girded with a group of researchers. Then it began to be released into the world and to be part of our lives, but never as now. We are currently in a kind of pandemic, where AI propagates in our existence as a virus, but not a bad virus, because I understand that the AI ​​often propagates with positive effects. Of course, although it is not a completely new thing, it is a very mysterious reality for us jurists. The problem begins that we can't even get a definition mostly accepted by experts of what AI is. First of all, we don't know what it is, because it is a moving entity that constantly changes. What we thought was ten years ago, today it will be an algorithm. In the areas of private life defense, or personal data, for example, or copyright, what does European legislation tell us in concrete terms? The AI ​​regulation [of the EU] is part of what we call “Data Package” [Data Package], it is inserted in the group of regulations that concern product security. But this is understood in very comprehensive terms, not only security as we are used to thinking about it, as something that calls into question physical integrity, but covers environmental issues, respect for fundamental values ​​and technology rights and data protection. It is true that the regulation has these practical aspirations and realization in some standards, but the idea is to develop with other existing regulations on data protection and intellectual property, and that does not conflict with them. We currently have ChatgPT on the American side, and DeepSeek on the Chinese side. Do you think China positions itself as a leader in the AI ​​area? China is found to be a colossus in the digital world. The way the world has been evolving has differentiated. 100 years ago we had war conflicts, and today we have wars where we continue to kill people, but we also have commercial wars and these technological wars. And I say that more than a war is a race to reach the new invention. The old blocks of countries have different strategies. For example, in the case of the United States of America (USA), this strategy has changed a lot with the presidency of Trump, but was always more liberal and "Laissez-Faire". This has also been the form of US action, but with Trump is more in the line of "Vale Tudo", what matters is to arrive first. There is a great promotion of technological companies, as you see with the great support they gave to Trump's presidential campaign. Then we have China, with a state policy, which is not so much in the hands of the private. There is a great focus on technological advancement, but it is visible that the country is already in a position that will hardly be achieved by others. Europe is not exactly well positioned.
Why? Europe has made the decision that the best way to develop technological progress and foster innovation is through hyper-regulation. There is no centimeter that is not regulated or not being regulated by the EU. Of course, it may have some advantages, and the aspirations can be in the face of controlled and sustainable development, and respect our fundamental rights and the rule of law. But I have some doubts. First, that this is achieved, because the protection of fundamental rights does not go through this hyper-regulation either. Then it seems to me that we are doing this at the expense of a value that seems to me, which is innovation. This idea comes, by the way, in the report of Mario Draghi, who warned the EU to the ability to mortgage future generations because we are leaving innovation behind. I don't see that any of these three technological models [US, China and EU] be particularly fruitful because they have benefits and disadvantages. We have an interesting model, which is the British. In what sense? The United Kingdom maintains the legal framework it inherited from the EU, and has not yet changed it. The United Kingdom will not adopt AI regulation [Europe's Ai Act], because it is no longer part of the EU, it seems that it will not create such a regulatory framework, but have an approach that is having a very generic picture that fixes the main points and limits, but then there will be a sectoral regulation. This regulation, which is still being created, is to establish the 'guidelines' for each area of ​​activity, so that there is autonomy in each sector and always respecting the particularities of each. In theory, it is more interesting, but everything is at first and I have not seen cases applied in practice. How do you comment on the use of AI in the legal and judicial area? Using sources that are not desirable to do our work was not something that came with ChatgPT. Speaking of something I know well, such as academic theses or scientific papers, it is not unprecedented that some less scrupulous authors quote sources in which they have never put their eyes, and then quote the wrong way, or quote sources that do not exist. There are situations in which unafable sources are cited, such as blogs, or papers that have not been subject to the peer review system. This is not new. We have the chatgpt beside it helps a lot and the temptation is great. I don't think it's the end of the world. Literacy was fundamental to the academy and any citizen. We all have to understand the benefits of Generative AI and risks as well. Research on Wikipedia pages can also generate errors. It is impossible to tell students not to use chatgPT, because this ban would be hollow. I can't know how people do their job. There may be situations of scientific dishonesty and situations where information is not true, but if someone tells me who wrote something with ChatgPT support, I have no problem with that. I have if the person is considered to be the author's author. ChatgPT works a lot as a Google search, it's not completely new. But I have to realize that the information that ChatgPT gives me has to be very analyzed and again investigated. ChatgPT can only give me clues where I can go, and then it can be useful and make us think. It is a source like any other, but it is not very credible. Chatgpt never deals with things in detail, for example.

item.title: Ruby Hui, President of the Macao Autism Association: “Autism differs from person to person”
item.description:
Created in 2012, the Macao Autism Association continues to fight for more care for children and young people with this development disturbance. But the association's president, Ruby Hui, warns of the need for more incisive policies for adolescents and their specific needs, especially in access to employment
What balance does the work done by the association in recent years? My work is above all to establish a connection with all the entities and resources made available by the government and also the game industry, as the authorities have started to [the context of the new game concession contracts] that develop more social support activities. Therefore, we have gathered all these resources to organize recreational activities for children and youth. In addition, we organize therapy sessions for our members. Usually, we request financial support from private companies and the government, covering 30 to 50 percent of these expenses. The support of the game sector is therefore quite important. Yes, but it has not really been a great support. For example, the government covers part of our monthly expenses, about 40,000 patacas. But this amount comes only to hire two full -time employees and one part -time employee. They are the ones who organize all activities, deal with the bureaucratic part, which includes the presentation of many reports to the government, because we ask for subsidies for almost half of our expenses. Therefore, do you consider that they need more support from the executive to be able to hire more professionals? Yes, it would be ideal. Associations like ours are getting bigger and the children we support are growing. I would say that 60 percent of our members are 11 or more, and about 20 percent are even larger, over 14 years old. We have to think about their future and the needs of therapy and treatment for adolescents, as it is not only small kids who need therapies such as speech or occupational therapy. They are young people who are still in high school and need to acquire different types of social skills, boys need to know how to deal with girls and vice versa. Then, when they become adults, they need to know how to deal with bosses in jobs. There are many valences to explore, but at this moment I would say that the supports are not enough. Are schools not yet prepared to receive these students, for example? Autism may be different from person to person. Students with autism, but who have better learning skills, are in normal schools. But parents tell me that there are not enough teachers with certain skills to deal with and teach these children. There are teachers who still have a very traditional mindset to treat these young people, who often have to deal with alone with bullying, for example. I would say that there are many children and young people with autism with psychological problems because of the school. When it speaks of the traditional mindset, what does this mean in concrete? In the case of my son, for example, he is obliged to always be sitting at school, but often likes to move and get up from his chair. From the point of view of parents who have children with this problem, there would be no problem, as long as it did not bother others, but for teachers it cannot be, and complain. They say things of the genre: "He will beat the table, he will move the painting, makes a lot of noise." Every day I receive complaints from parents to connect with the school, and for small situations like this. What are the main difficulties or challenges that Macao families face when they deal with an autistic child? In my case, my family is middle -class, and financially we are fine. But when my son was younger needed to do therapy and it was very expensive. Now these therapies cost even more. At the time my son was in primary education, 600 to 700 patacas was paid for each therapy session, but there are days a father told me that the sessions now cost about 1000 patacas per class, which is very expensive. Families of lower social classes cannot afford. Therefore, this support is one of the great objectives of our association, raising money so that we can provide explanations, therapy sessions or other type of support. All so that our members can attend classes with 50 percent discount, where the association pays half the amount. When the association was created, what were its main objectives? In 2012 autism was not a very spoken theme. Therefore, we joined [some parents and families] and we started to ask for support from the government and try to draw attention to the subject. We got some things because the government now gives more support to these young people, at least for those under 12. The problem we feel is that these young people are growing and adolescents need other types of supports that do not exist. What is necessary to change in mindsets and society in relation to autism? In Macao there are not many companies willing to hire young people with autism. Situation that is not seen in Hong Kong, where there are several hiring programs with social companies. Macau needs to follow this path. One day in Rio World Autism Consciousness Day is celebrated on April 2 and, in this context, the Macao Autism Association joined Sands China for a series of activities with children and parents, which took place last March 10th. Through the program “Sands Care”, the game operator provided a visit to the exhibition “Coastal Fantasia”, with the figure of “King Lobster”, a creation of Philip Colbert artist ” A boat trip through the Delta of the Pearl River. In total, 70 people participated. Quoted by a game operator statement, Ruby Hoi said the tour "allowed children to enjoy the maximum of the trip." "Thank you for all the support provided to people with autism in Macau, and I hope that all sectors of society can continue to support the development of these people and promote their inclusion in society," he said. For the game operator, this type of events can help “reinforce the cohesion of families dealing with autism, but also promote the awareness of society and support for the community of people with autism fostering a more inclusive and supportive social environment”.

item.title: Paul French, writer: Looking for Wallis Simpson in China
item.description:
The Rota das Letras literary festival, which starts on Friday, will feature the presence of writer Paul French, who launched last year a new biographical book, "Her Lotus Year", which describes Wallis Simpson's experience in China before being a Duchess of Windsor. The British author will also talk about “Destination Macau”, a nostalgic and almost cinematic account of the city's history
How did you come to the history of Wallis Simpson's life experience in China? I lived in Shanghai for many years and many visitors knew that Wallis Simpson had spent time in the city. Rumors ran on what he had done, and visitors always wanted to know if the rumors were true, such as the idea that she had learned esoteric sexual techniques or had posed naked for photographs. It was also said that he had belonged to a group of opium smuggling, or a group of bets that combined horses races. For me, as an author and expert in foreign experiences in Shanghai in the first half of the twentieth century, none of this made sense. So I thought this was the ideal time to really find out what Wallis had done in China. The fact that she was in the country in 1924 and 1925, two of the most fascinating years in the history of modern China, helped a lot. How do you describe the life of the duchess in the country during that specific political period? China was in total chaos when she was there, because Puyi, the last emperor, had been expelled from the forbidden city and occurred the biggest strikes ever in Hong Kong history. In addition, political fractions were recorded in Guangzhou, warlords of war in Shanghai and northern China. These were also the most wet years that there is a record in China, with crop production breaks and the occurrence of tiphoid and cholera fever outbreaks. He fired the number of bandits and pirates. Then, in March 1925, Sun Yat-Sen, leader of the Republican Revolution of 1911, died without leaving an obvious successor. Wallis came across all this, as he was retained on the island of Shamian, Guangzhou, while the city struggled; In Shanghai, he saw corpses to be brought to the city from the battles of the warlords; He saw victims of typhus and anger in Tianjin; and troops of the warlords threatening Beijing. But he was also largely in a foreign protective bubble that protected her from foreign soldiers and her white skin. He could delight in China's culture and aesthetics, while around him the whole country threatened to explode. How was the personality of Wallis Simpson, a controversial figure in the context of the marriage to the Duke of Windsor? It is very important not to confuse Wallis of 1924 with the later Wallis, from the long years of exile and controversy as Duchess of Windsor. In 1924 Wallis was only 28 years old, fleeing from a physically abusive husband (her first husband, Win Spencer, an American Navy commander) and was not yet particularly sophisticated or cosmopolitan. These were characteristics that would learn in China, mingling in the “colonies” [concessions] international foreign and bohemiums of Shanghai and Beijing. In fact, it was in Beijing that it first mixed with ambassadors, high -level Chinese politicians, high -ranking military officers and a stretch, and from them learned everything from playing Bridge and enjoying Jade to how to behave in high society. Obviously, this was useful a decade later when he met the Prince of Wales in England. Admittedly, the posterior Wallis, the Duchess, is a more difficult figure to like. Perhaps she and the Duke have made some bad political decisions and made some friendships, perhaps Wallis became a little bitter for not being accepted by the British royal family. But the truth is that in 1924 she was young, free of a bad husband and was in one of the most fascinating countries in the world. What can readers perceive this figure and about China of that time, with "Her Lotus Year"? China in 1925 was on the brink of potential explosion, as the whole country could have fallen into total chaos, dividing into the size of Portugal managed by warlords with private armies, or a resurgent Qing Dynasty supported by Japan in the North [China], the South and, of course, the foreign powers-England, America, France and Japan-who had Chinese lands like colonies. Ultimately, this did not happen, but no one knew this in 1925. Wallis herself oscillated between feeling incredibly comfortable and happy in what was her "year of lotus," as he described him, quoting Homer's Sopoifers who never want to return home; and feel terrified of the violence of the warlords or those who were against foreigners. What are the biggest challenges, as a writer, in the process of researching the history of Wallis? Wallis probably became the most photographed and spoken woman in history, more than Marilyn Monroe, more than Queen Isabel II. But in 1924 she was not famous at all. So it left a very difficult trail to follow. He wrote his memories, but these were "disinfected." A big problem was also the rumors that the British government and secret services circulated in 1936 in an attempt to destroy the idea of ​​a marriage between King Eduardo VIII and Wallis. The attempt failed because he abdicated the throne and they married, but these sexual rumors and insinuations, many of them racist and misogynists, have remained to this day, and they continue to be regularly recycled in the British and American Tabloid Press. I found the real Wallis a much more friendly character than I expected, and I hope readers will feel that too. Is invited to another edition of Rota das Letras. How do you feel for being part of the festival? I love to be part of the Macao Literary Festival. Although he had spoken before in Macao, namely in the Portuguese bookstore and other places, he had never participated in the festival. I look forward to being able to talk about Wallis Simpson and also about my new collection of rehearsals about Macau, entitled "Destination Macau". Some stories of Macao that have pleased me over the years, some of them presented with a more English look, as it were, may be interested and will be new to the local public. Book | “Destination Macau”, the city between “The Imaginary and the Real” Paul French has just launched the third volume of the “Destination” collection, which had editions of Shanghai or Beijing, and is now dedicated to telling stories of the ancient macao, a “place as imaginary as real”, as described the synopsis of the work. The work of the British author presents "The Macao by artists George Chinnery and George Smirnoff, the writers Deolinda da Conceição and Maurice Dekobra, to the fantasies of" Pulp Fiction "and febrile dreams of Josef Von Sternberg and Jean Delannoy." There is still no shortage of Paul French, stories around historical figures such as Pedro José Lobo and Ian Fleming, author and creator of James Bond. Macao of the time of World War II, those who “came to Macao in search of gold, and those who sought war refuge” is described, not forgetting “the combatants looking for a secret passage through the 'neutral' macao”. Paul French unveil mysteries or tells forgotten stories to many, such as the idea that Japan had tried to buy Macau in 1934 or the person who sailed with the Macau pirates queen, Lai Choi San. There are, in all, 18 stories “true of fascinating people who lived or visited Macau in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries”.

item.title: Augusto Nogueira, President of Artm: “Macau is ahead of Hong Kong”
item.description:
The Macao toxicode dependent rehabilitation association is 25 years old this year. Augusto Nogueira makes a positive balance of the fourth century that began with a small therapeutic community and reached international recognition. The Association's president argues that, in prevention, Macau is at the head of Hong Kong and that the use of synthetic drugs is not yet problematic in the territory
What balance does the work developed by ArtM in these 25 years? We do the balance very positive, because we started with a small area and a small therapeutic community. Nowadays we have a community with a capacity of 60 people, much more than the 15 we had at the time. We have developed several programs, namely the syringe distribution, which is a success, because it has led to a reduction and almost suppression of HIV contagion by people who inject drugs. For nine years there is the program and we have zero cases of infection. We developed support for social integration and follow -up after treatment, with “After Care”. We do preventive work in schools with the “Be Cool” program. We have the project “Hold on To Hope”, betting on vocational education, through coffee and the art gallery. It is a project that is well achieved and that turns out to be turned to tourism. We have visits from international entities and various non-governmental organizations, and the United Nations themselves. The most positive for us is to know how many people are recovered and who are well today. Unfortunately, we could not recover all people, but in each relapse there is always the possibility of the person coming again to do treatment. How many people have recovered in 25 years? We couldn't get this notion. We maintain contact with many people, but others have already left Macau, followed their lives. We have some contacts in the first two years after treatment, but then life goes on. People also want to go on a lifetime with no connection with the artm, sometimes marry and new companions don't know about their previous life and want to keep some confidentiality. But sometimes we meet. The other day they paid me a water without me knowing (laughs). These are small gestures that give us satisfaction to continue and make us believe that recovery is always possible. What are the big challenges to maintain the ArtM project in terms of space and financing? In terms of space and places for treatment we are well. The facilities are ten years old, there are maintenance problems, but this is more related to the panorama of construction in Macao. We need a space for the After Care, because what we have currently rented and is deteriorated. We are talking to the Institute of Social Action (IAS) to have a new space. With regard to the back, all our departments have financing, but we obviously seek support for our activities otherwise. Regarding the authorities' posture regarding consumption and treatment, do you understand that it is still conservative in relation to other countries and regions? This question is a little ambiguous. In terms of treatment and strategy in combating consumption, I think Macau is very ahead of Hong Kong, for example. In Macao, we have therapeutic community, we work on prevention and treatment, as well as our syringes and methadone distribution program. We have a range of treatments available to those in need. In the area of ​​prevention, the government has given a lot of support. The IAS has been quite open in strategies to combat consumption and prevention. In Hong Kong, for example, there is no syringe distribution program. Macao is from the few regions of Southeast Asia that has a government -supported syringes distribution program. But there could be another different interpretation of the law, with a differentiation between what is trafficking and their own consumption. For example, at this time if the person has a higher amount than that stipulated is soon considered trafficking, without proof. We think that in this case there should be a differentiation. It is then up to the police to investigate whether the quantities found are for consumption or trafficking. There should be an opening to give people more opportunities to be referred for treatment instead of going to prison. But lately, there have not been as many cases as that. How do you describe the current consumer profile in Macau? There is a large reduction in heroin consumption, and the few people who did so consume it today, or sleep. At this time the highest consumption is metabetamin, cannabis and some ketamine residues. As for the new synthetic drugs, there have been some records, but so far nothing alarming. But of course we have to be alert, we have to continue to do a good prevention job so that people are aware of the problems related to drug use. Regarding trafficking, we know that before the pandemic there was much cocaine trafficking to Macao, and after Covid-19 this situation almost ceased to happen. A good dissuasive work has been done and has to continue to be done so that there is less traffic to pass through Macau. It does not mean that there are no situations currently, but we are not in such a chaotic situation as that. Speaking of synthetic drugs and their consumption, which according to the latest United Nations report has reached a worrying situation around the world. What is your comment to the scenario described in the annual report of the International Narcotics Control Board? It is evident that the use of this type of drugs has been increasing over the years. Synthetic drugs are a real problem in the United States of America, for example, with fentanyl consumption, and Asia in some countries. It is a global problem because consumption and production are easy. Some of these drugs are made with other chemicals and many other products that are not well known to the origin and that can cause many overdoses. The UN suggests combating the production of ingredients that are used to produce these drugs, continue to reinforce the investigation to catch traffickers. But there are points of this report that it is necessary to follow, for many countries, which is the struggle between ideologies. In what sense? There is a struggle between those who argue that harm reduction is sufficient to combat all these problems that are arising, and that it is the solution to everything. Then we have those who think that harm reduction is not missing. In the artm we consider that there has to be a balance, because prevention is something important that cannot stop. What happened in Portugal, for example, when they liberalized the drug and failed to prevent and support treatment, [it was not good], and today Portugal is again in a slightly chaotic situation at consumption and trafficking. This means that prevention can never cease to exist. There should be quality treatments, with supervision of entities. The speed of access to treatment has to exist, and it can not be like in some countries where people have been waiting for a vacancy or permission to enter, as non -governmental organizations do not let the person enter until they receive the subsidy for each bed and patient. In these months a lot can happen. Damage reduction should be seen as a continuity for recovery, with rooms for consumption with medical and technical support, or syringe management programs. There is another problem, especially in Europe, which is heroin consumers, when they reach a more advanced age, already have many health problems and need sites to be, of a certain dignity. We have been wasting a lot of time with these ideological wars, and some of them exist for the sake of power, to influence the liberalization of drugs, and this is quite harmful. People's rights end when it begins to harm the rights of all other people, there must be a balance. As the report also says, there is a lack of medicines for some countries in Africa.
